resources.string: Coronavirus: Do you have a COVID plan ready?
Approaching a doctor for help and medical advise

Received a positive COVID diagnosis? Getting a COVID test is not the best piece of news to receive right now. However, once you get the news, it is important to decide the next course of action. While over 80% of cases are mild or moderate in nature, not every patient requires hospitalization. Knowing what to do, when to seek help can fasten your recovery time and help you get back on your feet better. Hence, it is important to have a COVID plan ready.

Aliquet lacus, pellentesque iaculis etiam porta. Porta lobortis mauris euismod nullam quis est vitae. Sed pharetra ultricies pellentesque risus ipsum. Quis egestas tortor sed ligula lectus at neque turpis morbi. Sed cursus venenatis vitae, faucibus ornare egestas eu. Vitae libero massa imperdiet etiam cras. Morbi sit urna iaculis pellentesque leo nec in. Sed euismod diam condimentum eu morbi turpis
Help the person who is sick follow their doctor’s instructions for care and medicine. For most people, symptoms last a few days, and people usually feel better after a week.
See if over-the-counter medicines for fever help the person feel better.
Make sure the person who is sick drinks a lot of fluids and rests.
Help them with grocery shopping, filling prescriptions, and getting other items they may need. Consider having the items delivered through a delivery service, if possible.

Have their doctor’s phone number on hand. Use CDC’s self-checker tool to help you make decisions about seeking appropriate medical care. Call their doctor if the person keeps getting sicker. For medical emergencies, call 911 and tell the dispatcher that the person has or might have COVID-19.
Ask help from your community. You can either ask for food or money. People are most likely to receive help within 4 days.
